snippet: A few investors who will not agree to take losses on their bonds expect Athens and its supporters to pay them back rather than go into default, a move that analysts said could set a dangerous precedent.
abstract: Greece is preparing to confront a small, well-financed group of holdout investors who are refusing to swap their bonds and take a 75 percent loss fresh off the largest debt restructuring in history; analysts say that if Athens pays back those investors rather than go into default, the move could set a dangerous precedent, angering other investors who took large losses and raising the prospect that Europe will cut deals with hedge funds holding risky sovereign debt.
lead_paragraph: A few investors who will not agree to take losses on their bonds expect Athens and its supporters to pay them back rather than go into default, a move that analysts said could set a dangerous precedent.

headline.seo: Greece Faces Off With Holdout Investors Over Debt
headline.main: Greece Is in a Face-Off With Its Bond Holdouts
headline.print_headline: Greece Is in a Face-Off With Its Bond Holdouts
